summary: The concept of "Senegal" within the context of EU legal and regulatory frameworks primarily pertains to its economic geography, particularly in relation to maritime activities and fisheries. The Senegalese economy heavily relies on halieutiques (fisheries), where the control and regulation of pêches (fishing) are crucial. The EU engages in triennial exercises to assess the incidence of fishing activities, ensuring hygienic practices among shipowners and fishermen. The Ministry of Fisheries (mptm) plays a vital role in the mobilization of resources, while logistical challenges affect landings of tuna and other produits. The tacit agreements between the EU and Senegal facilitate the apportioning of fishing quotas, benefiting both parties while respecting Senegal's sovereignty.
